Ca2+-activated Cl- secretion in native human airway epithelia requires activation of Ca2+-dependent basolateral K+ channels (hSK4).

SK4 is the gene that codes for the Gardos channel in red blood cells. This channel is important pathophysiologically, because it represents the major pathway for cell shrinkage via KCl and water loss that occurs in sickle cell disease.

K(Ca) channels presenting the pharmacology of SK4 channels are present on both apical and basolateral membranes, but it is the basolateral SK4-like channels that play a major role in calcium-dependent chloride secretion in 16HBE14o- cells.

activation of Gardos channel at different oxygen tensions is correlated with changes in passive and active calcium transport and sensitivity to calcium
stochastic Ca2+ permeabilization rather than Gardos-channel variation is the main determinant selecting which sickle cells dehydrate through Gardos channels in each sickling episode

kegg.name: Protein digestion and absorption - Homo sapiens (human)

summary: The protein encoded by this gene is part of a potentially heterotetrameric voltage-independent potassium channel that is activated by intracellular calcium. Activation is followed by membrane hyperpolarization, which promotes calcium influx. The encoded protein may be part of the predominant calcium-activated potassium channel in T-lymphocytes. This gene is similar to other KCNN family potassium channel genes, but it differs enough to possibly be considered as part of a new subfamily. [provided by RefSeq, Jul 2008].
